data.title: Pressing escape should always set focus to the text
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: WIn10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Press ctrl-shift-E 
2. Press escape, note that focus is not on the editor

data.title: How to specify CompletionItem order?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0-insider
- OS Version: win10

I'm working on a language server extension(ycmd for vscode).
Currently ycmd could give correct (ordered) completion results, but vscode sort it again with CompletionItem.label. I had tried to make sortText ordered like '1, 2, 3'. But it looks like not working.

Here is what ycmd returns: 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2534277/18407960/f35a0f60-7751-11e6-90ce-96bb5ec14d0f.png)

Here is what vscode shows:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2534277/18407963/ff013ee2-7751-11e6-993c-6bf5817b287c.png)

I've found related issue here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1403. It seems fixed, but currently could not work.

Thanks.

data.title: freezes opening passphrase-protected ssh git repository
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Arch linux 4.7.2-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Sat Aug 20 23:02:56 CEST 2016 x86_64 GNU/Linux
  Steps to Reproduce: 
1. open a folder containing an SSH git repo with passphrase-protected key
2. open konsole (a KDE terminal emulator), run `/opt/visual-studio-code/code &` 

Result: Vscode freezes. If I close the window, KDE says: "Application code is not responding" and giving me an option to terminate it.

Note:
If I run `/opt/visual-studio-code/code` in foreground, vscode does not freeze and I'm prompted for the passphrase:

```
Enter passphrase for key '/path/to/id_rsa':
```

data.title: Add support to get image size (width and height)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hi, opening an image in vs code only shows the image. It would be great if it could show more details also, like its size, width and height. 

Also, if possible with x2 and /2 calculated also along with the original size.

ex. (It would show something like this)
width: 180px
height: 180px

width@2x: 360px
height@2x: 360px

width/2: 90px
height/2: 90px

data.body: It would be awesome if you could provide simultaneous edit and preview on markdown files. Clicking on the preview button is not that UX friendly.

data.title: Format Code dosn't work with Javascript on OSX
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version:  OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1.   Open Javascript File
2.   Right click in editor window, select "Format Code"

Expected Action:
Code is formatted.

Actual Action:
Code doesn't change.

As a workaround I installed the extension beautify and it is able to format the code.

data.title: tabCompletion not correctly set
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Win7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start from any Angular 2 project: e.g: https://github.com/spboyer/ng2-startingline
2.  Make sure workspace settings have editor.tabCompletion: true

At some point, perhaps not right away, tab completion stops working. Looking at default settings, editor.tabCompletion is set to false, despite workspace settings showing that it is set to true.

data.title: A blocking process freezes entire ide.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:`1.5.1`
- OS Version:`ubuntu 16.4`

Steps to Reproduce:
1. execute a script with long for or something blocks the process 
2. in a native terminal the loop will not freeze the terminal  and stream the output of the loop however in vscode this process freezes the entire ide not even just terminal so you cannot even terminate the terminal without terminating entire vscode which can cost serious data loss in an unsaved workspace

data.title: 1.5 update crashed VS Code; required 'stable' reinstall
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5 
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise (64 bit)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Press blue button while in VS Code to download newest version (my previous was v1.4).
2. It stalls, but doesn't have a real issues at this point.
3. Stop VS Code.  
4. Download the 1.5 upgrade.
5. Install 1.5 upgrade.
6. VS Code no longer works.
7. Download 'stable' 1.5 version.
8. Restart computer.
9. Install 'stable' 1.5 version.
10. Everything is back to normal.  (Yay!)

Apologies I didn't take a pictures of the error messages.  Very impressive and informative, but gone now.  My priority sadly was solving the issue.  :)

data.title: Request for searching all texts or references
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 / Ubuntu

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open C/C++ or other language folder
2. Open a file
3. Right click on a variable/function/class name

No option is for finding all texts or references.

Currently, Visual Studio Code supports "Change All Occurrences". Finding references or texts support in Visual Studio edition or eclipse, but not in Visual Studio Code.

data.title: `angular` syntax profile from emmet doesn't work after 1.5.0 update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows [Version 6.1.7601]

Steps to Reproduce:

1 - Set the `angular` syntax profile in your `settings.json`, example:

```
{
    "emmet.syntaxProfiles": {
        "html": "angular"
    }
}
```

2 - Create a new HTML File

3 - Try to expand an emmet expression, example:

```
ul>li*5
```

3b - Or an angular-specific emmet expression, example:

```
md-content[layout="column"]>md-button{Save}
```

I noticed that both versions of VS Code: 1.4.0 and 1.5.1 have the same version of emmet installed (1.3.1).

data.title: Publicly accessible previous versions of VS Code

Request from #11766 

> Also, it would be nice if there was an official download source to downgrade to a prior version. Fortunately, I found one in my trash this time, but I will definitely be disabling auto update because of this for future releases.

data.title: Invalidating stale cache entries
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Win 8

I moved some files from one folder to another, and when I  use Ctrl+P to open some files, the suggestions still show the file in the old folder and the new, though it is only present in the new. The old entry is present in the 'recently opened' section. When clicked on the old entry, it just fails and asks if it should create a new file there. 

I tried reproducing it with a small project, but I can't seem to be able to, so I don't know how this came to be like this in the first place.

Nevertheless, can some option for the user in the menu to trigger invalidating cache and re-building it ? I couldn't find something like that, which might be useful in this as well as similar cases.

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5004036/18399019/2c3c46a0-769d-11e6-8d7f-d82d64323bed.PNG)
![capture2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5004036/18399018/2c3c014a-769d-11e6-9733-0e6c393586ea.PNG)

TIA

data.title: Explorer scrolls to top after deleting a file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: macOS

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Scroll down the list of files in the Explorer and delete a file.
2. Note that the after doing so you lose your scroll position and are sent to the top.

**Desired behavior**
Scroll position should be maintained IMO.  I may want to delete multiple files in the same general area.  So I would need to scroll back to the same spot each time I delete a file.

data.title: tsx attribute formatting removes bracket spacing
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. TypeScript Version: 2.*
2. `<input value={ this.state.value } />`
3. Format document

**Expected behavior:**
In **1.8.10** the spacing inside the brackets was unchanged on format operation (closing bracket `}` or format document).
`<input value={ this.state.value } />`

**Actual behavior:** 
In **2.**\* the space inside the brackets is always removed when formatting.

``` ts
<input value={this.state.value} />
```

Looks like it might be related to: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/9361

data.title: Quick opened files should be kept open, not previewed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: macOS
### Desired behavior

When you use Quick Open (<kbd>Cmd</kbd> + <kbd>P</kbd>) to open a file, that file should stay open (i.e. it shouldn't be a preview tab).
### Current behavior

Current behavior opens it as a preview tab, which can be undesirable.  If you open a lot of files up front through quick open, you have to double click the tab or run command "Keep Open" for each file.  It makes it very slow to open a lot of files from Quick Open.

![sep-09-2016 10-42-30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11839736/18396775/2bd6b2f4-767a-11e6-8ab7-540aa0be74a1.gif)

Since some people may want to rapidly preview a lot of files, then we should do what Sublime does in their version of Quick Open: upon keyboard focus or hover of any file in Quick Open, a preview tab is shown.  Only when you press Enter or click does it keep it as an editor and close the Quick Open.

If we click away from or press <kbd>Esc</kbd>in Quick Open, then this preview tab would close, unless there already was a preview tab open before using Quick Open (in that case the previously previewed file would appear as if nothing had ever happened, so we don't leave a mess).

data.title: Custom code completion does not show anymore
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Code your own CompletionItemProvider :-)
2. Try to use it...

It does resolve / return a list of CompletionItems but there are no suggestions displayed to the user.

The following code does not work:

``` typescript
export class ResolveCompletionItemProvider implements CompletionItemProvider {

    provideCompletionItems(document: TextDocument, position: Position, token: CancellationToken): CompletionItem[] {

        return [new CompletionItem('testlable'), new CompletionItem('test2')];
    }
}
```

If I set a breakpoint to the return statement, it is hit, but the suggestions are never shown.

Am I doing something wrong?

Cheers
Chris
